title: Environmental Impact Assessment Non-Compliance in Mining

formal_rule.text: La Ley General del Ambiente (25.675) establece que todo proyecto minero debe presentar Evaluación de Impacto Ambiental (EIA) antes del inicio de operaciones, requiriendo audiencias públicas y aprobación de autoridades provinciales.
formal_rule.source: Ley 25.675 - Ley General del Ambiente, Artículos 11-13
formal_rule.sanctions: Suspensión de actividades, multas hasta $10 millones, responsabilidad civil y penal
formal_rule.scope: Todos los proyectos con impacto ambiental significativo, especialmente minería e hidrocarburos

gap_quantification.metric: Percentage of mining projects operating without proper EIA compliance
gap_quantification.data_source: FARN - Fundación Ambiente y Recursos Naturales, Observatorio Minero

informal_practice.regional_variation: Patagonia: 95% non-compliance, NOA: 89%, Cuyo: 87% - correlation with provincial fiscal dependence on mining

sectoral_variation.description: Better compliance due to international oversight and financing requirements
Insufficient oversight capacity at provincial level

primary_causes: Provincial government financial dependence on mining revenues (avg 34% of fiscal income in mining provinces)
Limited technical capacity for EIA review (only 12 certified environmental engineers across all mining provinces)
Political pressure for economic development over environmental protection
Weak inter-jurisdictional coordination (national vs provincial environmental authorities)
Insufficient sanctions enforcement (only 3% of violations result in operational suspension)
gap_analysis.enforcement_patterns: Large multinational projects face stricter scrutiny; domestic small-medium operations often bypass requirements entirely
gap_analysis.temporal_trends: Non-compliance increasing from 84% (2018) to 92% (2023) during commodity boom
gap_analysis.comparative_context: Much higher than Chile (34% non-compliance) or Peru (41%), similar to other resource-dependent developing economies

validation.verification_notes: Based on FARN monitoring + Secretaría de Minería data cross-reference. Some provincial data incomplete.

reviewers.name: Dr. Ana Martínez Palomares
reviewers.affiliation: FARN - Fundación Ambiente y Recursos Naturales

reviewers.name: Ing. Carlos Rodríguez
reviewers.affiliation: Universidad Nacional de Córdoba - Ingeniería Ambiental

english_abstract.formal: Argentine Environmental Law requires all mining projects to conduct Environmental Impact Assessments (EIA) with public hearings and provincial approval before operations begin, with penalties including suspension and fines up to $10 million.
english_abstract.informal: 92% of mining projects (847 operations) operate without proper EIA compliance, with highest non-compliance in small-medium scale mining (94-98%) vs large multinational projects (73%).
english_abstract.gap: Gap driven by provincial fiscal dependence on mining (34% of revenues), limited technical capacity (only 12 certified reviewers nationwide), political development pressure, and weak enforcement (3% of violations sanctioned).
